Decentralized Aggregation for Energy-Efficient Federated Learning via Overlapped Clustering and D2D Communications

Mohammed S. Al-Abiad, Member, IEEE, Mohanad Obeed, Md. Jahangir Hossain, Senior Member, IEEE, and Anas Chaaban, Senior Member, IEEE The authors are with the School of Engineering, the University of British Columbia, Kelowna, BC V1V 1V7, Canada (e-mail: m.saif@alumni.ubc.ca, mohanad.obeed@ubc.ca, jahangir.hossain@ubc.ca, anas.chaaban@ubc.ca).
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a distributed machine learning (ML) technique to train models without sharing users’ private data. In this paper, we propose a decentralized FL scheme that is called federated learning empowered overlapped clustering for decentralized aggregation (FL-EOCD). The introduced FL-EOCD leverages device-to-device (D2D) communications and overlapped clustering to enable decentralized aggregation, where a cluster is defined as a coverage zone of a typical device. The devices located on the overlapped clusters are called bridge devices (BDs). In the proposed FL-EOCD scheme, a clustering topology is envisioned where clusters are connected through BDs, so as the aggregated models of each cluster is disseminated to the other clusters in a decentralized manner without the need for a global aggregator or an additional hop of transmission. Unlike the star-based FL, the proposed FL-EOCD scheme involves a large number of local devices by reusing the RRBs in different non-adjacent clusters. To evaluate our proposed FL-EOCD scheme as opposed to baseline FL schemes, we consider minimizing the overall energy-consumption of devices while maintaining the convergence rate of FL subject to its time constraint. To this end, a joint optimization problem, considering scheduling the local devices/BDs to the CHs and computation frequency allocation, is formulated, where an iterative solution to this joint problem is devised. Extensive simulations are conducted to verify the effectiveness of the proposed FL-EOCD algorithm over FL conventional schemes in terms of energy consumption, latency, and convergence rate.

Index Terms:
Device-to-device (D2D) communications, decentralized and low-latency federated learning, energy consumption, overlapped clustering.

I Introduction

Machine learning (ML) techniques have been leveraged to provide various services, such as virtual reality, traffic prediction, and object recognition [1, 2, 3]. The ML model training is usually implemented at the base station (BS) in a centralized manner, where the raw data is required to be collected at the BS for training coexist. However, in many applications, datasets are generated at edge devices, and consequently, transmitting raw data from all devices to BS incurs huge network traffic and devices data privacy leakage [4]. Therefore, the traditional centralized ML techniques are not preferable for next generation wireless networks [5]. Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising distributed machine learning (ML) algorithms for addressing the aforementioned bandwidth and privacy challenges [6, 7].

I-A Federated Learning at the Network Edge

The popular FL conventional architectures are: (i) star-based FL architecture [8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13] and (ii) relay-assisted/dual-hop FL [14, 15, 16, 17], also called hierarchical FL. In each iteration of the star-based FL, each device trains a local model based on its own dataset and then transmits its local trained model to the BS. The BS then aggregates all the received models into one global model and broadcasts it back to the devices. These procedures are repeated several rounds until the global model converge. Similar to the star-based FL, the hierarchical FL requires the BS to aggregate all the local models of the devices, which are collected by cluster-heads (CHs) (or relays). In particular, two-hop transmission is required in the hierarchical FL, i.e., the CHs/relays need to forward the local models of devices to the BS. Despite the fact that hierarchical FL can improve the limited connectivity of devices and reduce their energy consumption, its main limitation, as previously mentioned, is that it requires two-hop transmission. However, these FL conventional architectures pose prime concerns for the wireless edge since the devices may exhibit: (i) significant heterogeneity in their computational resources (e.g., limited battery and CPU computations) [18]; (ii) varying proximity to the BS (e.g., varying distances from devices to the BS in a cell). As a consequence, a significant amount of energy is consumed to bounce the model between the BS and the devices [8]. This consumes the power of the battery-powered devices and the available resources at the BS that may be used for another set of devices.

Towards energy-efficient FL while offloading the BS for performing global aggregations, we consider a new angle for developing resource-efficient and decentralized FL using device-to-device (D2D) communications [19]. D2D communications has been demonstrated to be a promising technology in 5G and beyond, such as fog computing and IoT systems [20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25]; indeed, it is expected that 50%percent5050\% of all network connections will be machine-to-machine by 2023 [26]. For example, D2D communications has been shown to be promising for significantly improving the energy efficiency, the reliability, and the data rate [20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25]. Unlike the hierarchical FL that can also use D2D clustering, we propose to overlap the clusters such that there is no need to have an additional level of aggregation at the BS, which may consume more energy. Therefore, it is imperative to exploit D2D communications and introduce a novel decentralized FL scheme for tackling the aforementioned issues of the FL conventional schemes.

Recently, a hybrid FL scheme that integrates the star-based topology with D2D communications, called semi-decentralized FL, was designed in [27]. The authors exploited D2D communications to propose a consensus mechanism to mitigate model divergence via low-power communications among nearby devices. However, the main limitation of the semi-decentralized FL in [27] is that it uses a global aggregator and two-time scale FL (i.e., D2D communications and device-to-BS wireless transmissions). Different from the work in [27], we design a novel decentralized FL scheme that clusters devices in a way that the models of each cluster is implicitly shared to the other clusters without the need for additional stage of aggregation at the BS. To this end, we propose a novel decentralized FL and resource allocation D2D paradigm to minimize the overall energy consumption of a delay-constrained FL in a partially connected D2D system. In the envisioned system, each single-antenna device has a limited coverage zone, named cluster, and dynamically works as: (i) a local device; (ii) a bridge device (BD); or (iii) a CH that can aggregate the models of the associated local devices and BD in its cluster.

I-B Related Works and Challenges

Since the devices are battery-driven, for a sustainable operation of an FL framework in latency-sensitive applications, it is crucial to reduce the energy consumption of the edge devices and the FL time that consists of computation and communication latency. Therefore, we will focus on works addressing resource efficiency and latency-constrained FL, which is the main focus of this paper. Specifically, star-based and hierarchical latency-constrained FL schemes will be reviewed in this section and evaluated in the numerical results section. For a comprehensive survey of the FL literature, we refer the reader to e.g., [28].

Several works extensively considered star-based FL from different aspects, such as frequency computation, wireless communications, and radio resource management, e.g., [8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13]. Another set of works investigated the impact of wireless link conditions, number of collaborating edge devices, and computation frequency allocation on the performance of star-based FL [10, 11, 12, 13]. However, these works mainly relied on the BS for global aggregations. To reduce the demand for global aggregations, a set of works considered a hierarchical system with two-hop transmission, e.g., [14, 15, 16, 17], [29]. For example, the authors in [29] developed a hierarchical FL model where edge servers perform partial global aggregations. As mentioned before, such a hierarchical FL model leads to increasing the energy consumption and delay.

For developing energy-efficient FL, several works considered minimizing communication and computation energy, e.g., [30, 31, 32, 33]. In [30], the authors proposed an energy-efficient radio resource allocation for delay constrained FL, where they minimized the communication energy and ignored the computation energy. In [32], radio resource allocation was developed to minimize both the communication and computation energy in an FL system subject to delay constraints. The authors in [33] proposed joint transmit power and computation frequency allocation to reduce the overall energy consumption of an FL in a fog-aided internet of things (IoT) network. Recently, a joint optimization framework considering device scheduling, transmit power allocation, and device’s computation frequency allocation was proposed to simultaneously minimize the total energy consumption and maximize the number of the scheduled devices [34]. However, an energy-efficient framework, while jointly considering communication and computation energy, for facilitating FL for network edge devices in partially connected D2D networks was not investigated in the existing literature.

Different from the aforementioned works, our goal is to propose a scheme, called federated learning empowered overlapped clustering for decentralized aggregation (FL-EOCD), that: (i) involves a decentralized FL scheme without a global aggregation at the BS; (ii) incorporates both local model training and CHs’ aggregated models dissemination among the CHs through the BDs; and (iii) develops an innovative clustering method leading to a computationally efficient solution. However, the proposed FL-EOCD scheme exhibits the following two challenges.

  1. 1.

    Challenge I: Unlike the aforementioned FL conventional systems where the optimization is performed only over the device scheduling and computation capability of collaborating devices, the optimization in the considered D2D environment also considers the selection of the set of CHs to achieve the best FL network performance. Therefore, the performance of FL (i.e., accuracy and convergence) jointly depends on the selection of CHs, scheduled devices, RRB resource allocation, and computation frequency allocation of the scheduled devices. Therefore, to fully capitalize the advantage of D2D communications, we must carefully consider a joint optimization of the CHs selection, device and RRB scheduling, and computation frequency allocation of the devices.

  2. 2.

    Challenge II: In practice, there is a trade-off between the FL time (i.e., computation time and wireless transmission latency) and edge device energy consumption; since reducing the FL time requires more energy. However, the computation time of devices is affected by the allocated computing resources, and increasing the computation frequency of the devices can reduce the latency at the cost of the increased energy consumption. Furthermore, the wireless data transmission latency is determined by the wireless transmission rate, which is related to wireless transmission power. To reduce the wireless communication latency, we can increase the transmission power, however this will consume more energy. Accordingly, a joint optimization of the degrees-of-freedom, namely, CHs selection, device scheduling to the CHs/RRBs, and computation frequency allocation, is required to satisfy a given FL time constraint and reduce energy consumption.

I-C Contributions

The specific contributions of this work are summarized as follows.

  • •

    We introduce a decentralized FL scheme, called FL-EOCD, which augments the conventional star-based and hierarchical FL architectures with overlapped clustering that enables global models dissemination without the need for a central aggregation at the BS. In FL-EOCD, the local models are trained at the devices and transmitted to the scheduled CHs for aggregation. Meanwhile, the BDs exploit their connectivity between the CHs to disseminate the received aggregated models among all the CHs in the network. Different from conventional FL schemes, FL-EOCD scheme clusters devices in a way that the models of each cluster is implicitly shared to the other clusters, where the aggregation is implemented in a distributed manner. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, this is the first work that introduces a decentralized FL scheme to efficiently deal with convergence rate, energy-efficiency, and learning time without involving a BS for aggregations.

  • •

    We develop an energy-efficient framework to facilitate the introduced FL-EOCD scheme for the energy-limited devices in the partially connected D2D network. We formulate an optimization problem to minimize both the computation and communication energy consumption of the devices subject to constraints on FL time, device connectivity, scheduling among the device-CH/RRB, and computation frequency allocation. The proposed joint optimization problem is NP-hard, and thus the global optimal solution is computationally intractable. To tackle such difficult optimization problem, an iterative solution framework is devised. Specifically, the overall CH selection, device-CH scheduling, and computation frequency allocation problem is decomposed into two sub-problems, namely, CHs selection and their devices scheduling sub-problem and computation frequency allocation sub-problem. For each sub-problem, we propose a solution of polynomial computational complexity, and rigorously justify the effectiveness of the proposed solutions. By iteratively solving these sub-problems, an FL-EOCD algorithm is developed to minimize the energy consumption.

  • •

    The effectiveness of the proposed FL-EOCD scheme is verified and compared with the existing FL schemes via simulations. Simulation results show that the proposed FL-EOCD scheme achieves 55%percent5555\% (30%percent3030\%) and 35%percent3535\% (50%percent5050\%) lower energy consumption and shorter FL time, respectively, compared to the considered star-based and hierarchical FL schemes. In terms of convergence rate, if the required accuracy is low (e.g., 80%percent8080\%), the proposed scheme requires more global iterations (around 3%percent33\% more) than the star-based and the hierarchical FL schemes. If the required accuracy is high (e.g., >93%absentpercent93>93\%), the proposed, star-based, and hierarchical schemes need the same number of global iterations.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. The system model is described in Section II. The optimization problem formulation is provided in Section III. The proposed solution is presented in Section IV. Section V presents an overview of the properties of the FL-EOCD algorithm. The simulation results and the concluding remarks are provided in Section VI and Section VII, respectively.

II System Model and Federated Learning

II-A System Overview

We consider a partially connected D2D network with a single BS and a set of devices that is denoted by 𝒩={1,2,⋯,N}𝒩12⋯𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,2,\cdots,N\}. An example of the envisioned system model is illustrated in Fig. 1. Each device n𝑛n has a limited coverage zone that represents the service area of that device within a circle of radius 𝚁𝚁\mathtt{R}. Such a service area is denoted in this work as a cluster. It is assumed that the clusters are formed based on the ability of devices to conduct low-energy D2D communications, e.g., geographic proximity. Therefore, the set of devices in the n𝑛n-th device’s cluster is defined by 𝒜n={m∈𝒩|dn,m≤𝚁\mathcal{A}_{n}=\{m\in\mathcal{N}|d_{n,m}\leq\mathtt{R}}, where dn,msubscript𝑑𝑛𝑚d_{n,m} is the distance between the n𝑛n-th device and the m𝑚m-th device. It is assumed that each device cannot transmit and receive at the same time, i.e., half-duplex D2D channel is adopted, and each device is equipped with a single antenna. Meanwhile, the BS in this work is not engaged in the FL global aggregation model and it is responsible for the scheduling process only. In particular, it decides the CH/BD selection and local device-CH association and delivers the scheduling parameters to the CHs/BDs over reliable control and non-payload communication (CNPC) channels.

The FL model training is considered through a sequence of global iterations indexed by t={1,2,⋯,T}𝑡12⋯𝑇t=\{1,2,\cdots,T\} as it will be explained in the next subsection. In each global iteration, devices have fixed locations and can change their locations in different global iterations [27, 13]. Subsequently, at any FL global iteration, the set of devices 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} is divided into: i) a subset of devices that can perform local learning on their dataset, this subset of devices are called local devices, ii) a subset of devices that can perform local learning and aggregate the local models of devices in their clusters which are denoted by cluster heads (CHs), and iii) a subset of devices that can perform local learning and combine the received aggregated models from adjacent CHs with their own local models and forward them back to the adjacent CHs for aggregated model disseminations; this subset of devices are called bridge devices (BDs). Let 𝒩l={1,2,⋯,Nl}subscript𝒩𝑙12⋯subscript𝑁𝑙\mathcal{N}_{l}=\{1,2,\cdots,N_{l}\} be the subset of local devices; 𝒞={1,2,⋯,C}𝒞12⋯𝐶\mathcal{C}=\{1,2,\cdots,C\} is the subset of CHs; ℬ={1,2,⋯,B}ℬ12⋯𝐵\mathcal{B}=\{1,2,\cdots,B\} is the subset of BDs; where 𝒩l∪𝒞∪ℬ∈𝒩subscript𝒩𝑙𝒞ℬ𝒩\mathcal{N}_{l}\cup\mathcal{C}\cup\mathcal{B}\in\mathcal{N}. For simplicity and unless otherwise stated, 𝒩lsubscript𝒩𝑙\mathcal{N}_{l} represents the set of scheduled devices and BDs, since the BDs can also perform local learning.

We propose that the local devices and BDs transmit their local models to their assigned CHs via D2D links using orthogonal RRBs in an uplink phase. Specifically, each CH is granted a limited number of Z𝑍Z orthogonal RRBs that are denoted by the set 𝒵={1,2,⋯,Z}𝒵12⋯𝑍\mathcal{Z}=\{1,2,\cdots,Z\}, where local devices can use them to transmit their trained models to the scheduled CHs. Each RRB is used to denote a time/frequency resource block of each CH, i.e., a group of orthogonal sub-carriers [35, 36]. In this work, we consider that each local device is scheduled to only one RRB, and each RRB is assigned to only one local device. Thus, we consider the following two binary optimization variables for local device-CH assignment: (i) sn,c=1subscript𝑠𝑛𝑐1s_{n,c}=1 if the n𝑛n-th device is assigned to the c𝑐c-th CH and sn,c=0subscript𝑠𝑛𝑐0s_{n,c}=0 otherwise; and (ii) rc,zn=1subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑛𝑐𝑧1r^{n}_{c,z}=1 if the n𝑛n-th device is allocated to the c𝑐c-th CH on the z𝑧z-th RRB, and rc,zn=0subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑛𝑐𝑧0r^{n}_{c,z}=0 otherwise.

Let pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} denote the transmission power of the n𝑛n-th device, and consequently, the achievable rate of the n𝑛n-th device to the c𝑐c-th CH over the z𝑧z-th RRB can be given by Rc,zn=W​log2⁡(1+rc,zn​pn​|hc,zn|2N0),∀c∈𝒜nformulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑛𝑐𝑧𝑊subscript21subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑛𝑐𝑧subscript𝑝𝑛superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑛𝑐𝑧2subscript𝑁0for-all𝑐subscript𝒜𝑛R^{n}_{c,z}=W\log_{2}(1+\frac{r^{n}_{c,z}p_{n}\left|h^{n}_{c,z}\right|^{2}}{N_{0}}),\forall c\in\mathcal{A}_{n}, where W𝑊W is the bandwidth per RRB, N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} denotes the additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) variance, and hc,znsubscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑛𝑐𝑧h^{n}_{c,z} denotes the D2D channel between the n𝑛n-th device and the c𝑐c-th CH over the z𝑧z-th RRB. Similarly, let hcnsubscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑛𝑐h^{n}_{c} denote the D2D channel between the c𝑐c-th CH and the n𝑛n-th scheduled device. Then, the achievable rate of D2D pair (c,n)𝑐𝑛(c,n) is given by Rcn=W​log2⁡(1+sn,c​pc​|hcn|2N0)subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑛𝑐𝑊subscript21subscript𝑠𝑛𝑐subscript𝑝𝑐superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑛𝑐2subscript𝑁0R^{n}_{c}=W\log_{2}(1+\frac{s_{n,c}p_{c}\left|h^{n}_{c}\right|^{2}}{N_{0}}). Consequently, the c𝑐c-th CH adopts a common transmission rate Rcsubscript𝑅𝑐R_{c} that is equal to the minimum achievable rates of all its scheduled devices that is denoted by 𝒩lcsuperscriptsubscript𝒩𝑙𝑐\mathcal{N}_{l}^{c}. This adopted transmission rate is Rc=minn∈𝒩lc⁡Rcnsubscript𝑅𝑐subscript𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑙𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑛𝑐R_{c}=\min_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{l}^{c}}R^{n}_{c}.

II-B Federated Learning Process

We propose an FL-EOCD scheme that has distinguishing features compared to the conventional FL schemes, e.g., star-based FL models [8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13] and hierarchical FL models [14, 15, 16, 17]. Particularly, our envisioned scheme learns the local models at devices and aggregates a shared global model through CHs and BDs without the need for global aggregations at the BS.

Let 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} denote the local data set of the n𝑛n-th local device, which represents a set of data samples {xi,yi}subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖\{x_{i},y_{i}\}, where xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} is the sample i𝑖i’s input (e.g., image pixels) and yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is the sample i𝑖i’s output (e.g., label of the image). Here, 𝒟n={(xi,yi):i=1,⋯,Dn}subscript𝒟𝑛conditional-setsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1⋯subscript𝐷𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n}=\{(x_{i},y_{i}):i=1,\cdots,D_{n}\} denotes the dataset involved in the training process of the n𝑛n-th local device. The total dataset involved in the training process in the system is 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. A widely used model in linear regression, logistic regression, and deep neural networks is considered, where the local loss function on the dataset of the n𝑛n-th local device can be calculated as

Ln​(𝐰)=1|𝒟n|​∑(xi,yi)∈𝒟nli​(𝐰),∀n∈𝒩l,formulae-sequencesubscript𝐿𝑛𝐰1subscript𝒟𝑛subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝒟𝑛subscript𝑙𝑖𝐰for-all𝑛subscript𝒩𝑙L_{n}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}_{n}|}\sum_{(x_{i},y_{i})\in\mathcal{D}_{n}}l_{i}(\mathbf{w}),\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{l}, (1)

where |𝒟n|subscript𝒟𝑛|\mathcal{D}_{n}| is the total number of data samples of the n𝑛n-th local device and 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} is the learning model parameter vector. For simplicity, we define Dn=|𝒟n|subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝒟𝑛D_{n}=|\mathcal{D}_{n}|. Here, li​(𝐰)subscript𝑙𝑖𝐰l_{i}(\mathbf{w}) is the loss function that measures the local training model error of the i𝑖i-th data sample. Common examples of loss function li​(𝐰)subscript𝑙𝑖𝐰l_{i}(\mathbf{w}) include linear regression with li​(𝐰)=0.5​‖𝒙iT​𝐰−yi‖2subscript𝑙𝑖𝐰0.5superscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝒙𝑇𝑖𝐰subscript𝑦𝑖2l_{i}(\mathbf{w})=0.5\|\boldsymbol{x}^{T}_{i}\mathbf{w}-y_{i}\|^{2} and support vector machine with li​(𝐰)=max⁡{0,1−yi​𝒙iT​𝐰},yi∈{−1,1}formulae-sequencesubscript𝑙𝑖𝐰01subscript𝑦𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒙𝑇𝑖𝐰subscript𝑦𝑖11l_{i}(\mathbf{w})=\max\{0,1-y_{i}\boldsymbol{x}^{T}_{i}\mathbf{w}\},y_{i}\in\{-1,1\} [11, 37]. In what follows, we explain the FL process of our advised learning model.

(1) FL process: In the envisioned FL-EOCD process, there are global iterations and local iterations. The specific process of the proposed FL-EOCD at the t𝑡t-th global iteration can be summarized as follows, which is presented in Fig. 2.

  • •

    The BS judiciously determines a subset of local devices 𝒩l={1,2,⋯,Nl}subscript𝒩𝑙12⋯subscript𝑁𝑙\mathcal{N}_{l}=\{1,2,\cdots,N_{l}\} to independently train local ML models and subsets of CHs and BDs;

  • •

    Each CH c𝑐c sends its updated aggregated model 𝐰c​(t−1)subscript𝐰𝑐𝑡1\mathbf{w}_{c}(t-1) to its scheduled devices 𝒩lcsubscriptsuperscript𝒩𝑐𝑙\mathcal{N}^{c}_{l} and the associated BDs in a downlink phase. Note that adjacent CHs transmit the aggregated models simultaneously using orthogonal RRBs and the CHs of the non-adjacent clusters can transmit their aggregated models to the selected local devices on the same RRB.

  • •

    Each selected device n∈𝒩l𝑛subscript𝒩𝑙n\in\mathcal{N}_{l} executes a local update algorithm (e.g., stochastic gradient descent (SGD) algorithm) based on its dataset 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} and the aggregated model 𝐰c​(t−1)subscript𝐰𝑐𝑡1\mathbf{w}_{c}(t-1) of its associated CH c𝑐c. The output of this local learning at the n𝑛n-th device is the updated local model 𝐰c,n∗​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑐𝑛𝑡\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c,n}(t);

  • •

    Meanwhile, BDs receive the aggregated models 𝐰c​(t−1)subscript𝐰𝑐𝑡1\mathbf{w}_{c}(t-1) from the associated CHs 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}, perform a local learning algorithm, aggregate the received models and their own updated models, forward the aggregated models to the corresponding CHs at the uplink phase of each iteration. This ensures the dissemination of the aggregated models of the CHs over the entire network. On the other hand, each CH can subtract its previous model from the received aggregated model of the BDs to retrieve the aggregated model of the adjacent CH(s) as will be explained next.

We define the loss function for the c𝑐c-th CH as the average local loss across the c𝑐c-th cluster,

L^​(𝐰)=1∑n|𝒟n|​∑n=1Nlc|𝒟n|​Ln​(𝐰).^𝐿𝐰1subscript𝑛subscript𝒟𝑛subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑁𝑐𝑙𝑛1subscript𝒟𝑛subscript𝐿𝑛𝐰\hat{L}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{\sum_{n}|\mathcal{D}_{n}|}\sum^{N^{c}_{l}}_{n=1}|\mathcal{D}_{n}|L_{n}(\mathbf{w}). (2)

The global loss function L​(𝝎)𝐿𝝎L(\boldsymbol{\omega}) is then defined as the average loss across all the clusters,

L​(𝐰)=1∑n|𝒟n|​∑n=1Nl|𝒟n|​Ln​(𝐰).𝐿𝐰1subscript𝑛subscript𝒟𝑛subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑁𝑙𝑛1subscript𝒟𝑛subscript𝐿𝑛𝐰L(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{\sum_{n}|\mathcal{D}_{n}|}\sum^{N_{l}}_{n=1}|\mathcal{D}_{n}|L_{n}(\mathbf{w}). (3)

The objective of the FL model training is to find the optimal model parameters 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} for L​(𝐰)𝐿𝐰L(\mathbf{w}) that is expressed as follows 𝐰∗=arg⁡min𝐰⁡L​(𝐰)superscript𝐰subscript𝐰𝐿𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*}=\arg\min_{\mathbf{w}}L(\mathbf{w}). Next, we explain in details the operations that are performed at the CHs and the BDs.

(2) BD and CH aggregation process: For simplicity of the ensuing analysis, we explain the operations that should be implemented at the CHs and BDs through an example. Consider an example of the envisioned FL model that is shown in Fig. 3, where the CHs and their scheduled devices and BDs are given. Suppose that each CH is granted 444 RRBs where local devices can transmit their local models. We first explain the operations of the CHs and BDs based on the overlapped chain clustering as in Fig. 3, then we generalize the operations for any number of clusters and any form of clustering structure. For notations convenience, here, we use cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} to denote the cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}-th CH, while in the remaining sections we use the notation c𝑐c for the c𝑐c-th CH.

Iteration 1: The c1subscript𝑐1c_{1}-th, c2subscript𝑐2c_{2}-th, and c3subscript𝑐3c_{3}-th CHs transmit their initial models 𝐰ci​(0)subscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖0\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(0) to the associated devices. For example, the c1subscript𝑐1c_{1}-th CH transmits its model 𝐰c1​(0)subscript𝐰subscript𝑐10\mathbf{w}_{c_{1}}(0) to the n1subscript𝑛1n_{1}-th and n2subscript𝑛2n_{2}-th devices, and the b1,2subscript𝑏12b_{1,2}-th BD. The c1subscript𝑐1c_{1}-th and c3subscript𝑐3c_{3}-th CHs can broadcast their models on the same RRB, while the c2subscript𝑐2c_{2}-th CH uses different RRB. Accordingly, the b1,2subscript𝑏12b_{1,2}-th and b2,3subscript𝑏23b_{2,3}-th BDs receive the models from the c1subscript𝑐1c_{1}-th and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2}-th CHs and the c2subscript𝑐2c_{2}-th and c3subscript𝑐3c_{3}-th CHs, respectively. Afterword, each device executes the local learning algorithm, whose output is 𝐰ci,n∗​(1)subscriptsuperscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖𝑛1\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c_{i},n}(1), i.e., 𝐰1,1∗​(1)subscriptsuperscript𝐰111\mathbf{w}^{*}_{1,1}(1) represents the local model of the n1subscript𝑛1n_{1}-th device that is scheduled to the c1subscript𝑐1c_{1}-th CH. While the devices do the local learning, the bi,jsubscript𝑏𝑖𝑗b_{i,j}-th BD picks one model from the received ones (i.e., 𝐰ci​(0)subscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖0\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(0) or 𝐰cj​(0)subscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑗0\mathbf{w}_{c_{j}}(0)) or both of them after aggregation to update its own model 𝐰di​j​(0)subscript𝐰subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗0\mathbf{w}_{d_{ij}}(0) using its available dataset. Hence, the di,jsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑗d_{i,j}-th BD has now three models which are 𝐰bi,j​(1)subscript𝐰subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗1\mathbf{w}_{b_{i,j}}(1), 𝐰ci​(0)subscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖0\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(0), and 𝐰cj​(0)subscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑗0\mathbf{w}_{c_{j}}(0). The bi,jsubscript𝑏𝑖𝑗b_{i,j}-th BD then aggregates these three models as follows

𝐰bi,ja​g(1)=1Dci+Dcj+Dbi,j(Dci𝐰ci(0)+Dcj𝐰cj(0)+Dbi,j𝐰bi,j(1)),superscriptsubscript𝐰subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗𝑎𝑔11subscript𝐷subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝐷subscript𝑐𝑗subscript𝐷subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗subscript𝐷subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖0subscript𝐷subscript𝑐𝑗subscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑗0subscript𝐷subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗subscript𝐰subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗1\mathbf{w}_{b_{i,j}}^{ag}(1)=\frac{1}{D_{c_{i}}+D_{c_{j}}+D_{b_{i,j}}}(D_{c_{i}}\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(0)+D_{c_{j}}\mathbf{w}_{c_{j}}(0)\\ +D_{b_{i,j}}\mathbf{w}_{b_{i,j}}(1)), (4)

At the uplink phase of the first iteration, each local device transmits its updated model, while each BD transmits the aggregated model given in (4).

It is important to note that once the model received by a CH or a BD, they first remove the models that they know from the previous iterations.

Iteration 3 and beyond: At the third iteration, we can notice that the model of the c3subscript𝑐3c_{3}-th CH is attained by the c1subscript𝑐1c_{1}-th CH and vise versa but with a delay of two iterations. In the third iteration and in the next ones, each CH first aggregates the models of the associated devices, cleans the models received from the associated BDs by removing the known previous models, aggregates the devices’ model with the models received by the associated BD(s), and then broadcasts back to the associated devices. Whereas, each BD first cleans the received models, conducts local learning to update its own model, aggregates the received models with the updated one, transmits to the associated CHs.

(3) Local learning process: We consider the SGD algorithm to solve the local training problem of devices. Let 𝐰ci,nt~​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐰~𝑡subscript𝑐𝑖𝑛𝑡\mathbf{w}^{\tilde{t}}_{c_{i},n}(t) denote the local model parameter of the n𝑛n-th local device with the associated cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}-th CH at the t𝑡t-th global round and the t~~𝑡\tilde{t}-th local iteration. Define 𝐰ci,n∗​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖𝑛𝑡\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c_{i},n}(t) as the local model parameter of the n𝑛n-th local device with the associated cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}-th CH at the t𝑡t-th global iteration after the local iterations are converged, which can be expressed as

𝐰ci,n∗​(t)=arg⁡min𝐰ci​∇Ln​(𝐰ci​(t)).subscriptsuperscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖𝑛𝑡subscriptsubscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖∇subscript𝐿𝑛subscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c_{i},n}(t)=\arg\min_{\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}}\nabla L_{n}(\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(t)). (10)

The local model parameter 𝐰ci,nt~​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐰~𝑡subscript𝑐𝑖𝑛𝑡\mathbf{w}^{\tilde{t}}_{c_{i},n}(t) in the t~~𝑡\tilde{t}-th local iteration is updated according to the gradient of Ln​(𝐰ci​(t))subscript𝐿𝑛subscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖𝑡L_{n}(\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(t)) and the learning rate δ𝛿\delta, i.e.,

𝐰ci,nt~+1​(t)=𝐰ci,nt~​(t)−δ​∇Ln​(𝐰ci,nt~​(t)),subscriptsuperscript𝐰~𝑡1subscript𝑐𝑖𝑛𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝐰~𝑡subscript𝑐𝑖𝑛𝑡𝛿∇subscript𝐿𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐰~𝑡subscript𝑐𝑖𝑛𝑡\mathbf{w}^{\tilde{t}+1}_{c_{i},n}(t)=\mathbf{w}^{\tilde{t}}_{c_{i},n}(t)-\delta\nabla L_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{\tilde{t}}_{c_{i},n}(t)), (11)

where 𝐰ci,n0​(t)=𝐰ci​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐰0subscript𝑐𝑖𝑛𝑡subscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}^{0}_{c_{i},n}(t)=\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(t) because it is the initial value and can be obtained from the cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}-th CH. Since 𝐰ci,n∗​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖𝑛𝑡\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c_{i},n}(t) is the converged local model parameter, we have

The local iterations are continued until the local model accuracy ϵlsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙\epsilon_{l} is reached, which is defined as Gn​(𝐰ci,nt~​(t))−Gn​(𝐰ci,n∗​(t))≤ϵl​[Gn​(𝐰ci​(t))−Gn​(𝐰ci∗​(t))]subscript𝐺𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐰~𝑡subscript𝑐𝑖𝑛𝑡subscript𝐺𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖𝑛𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙delimited-[]subscript𝐺𝑛subscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖𝑡subscript𝐺𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖𝑡G_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{\tilde{t}}_{c_{i},n}(t))-G_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c_{i},n}(t))\leq\epsilon_{l}[G_{n}(\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(t))-G_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{*}_{c_{i}}(t))]. On the other hand, the global iteration continues until the global model accuracy ϵgsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔\epsilon_{g} is reached, which is defined as L​(𝐰​(t))−L​(𝐰∗)≤ϵg​[L​(𝐰0)−L​(𝐰∗)]𝐿𝐰𝑡𝐿superscript𝐰subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔delimited-[]𝐿superscript𝐰0𝐿superscript𝐰L(\mathbf{w}(t))-L(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq\epsilon_{g}[L(\mathbf{w}^{0})-L(\mathbf{w}^{*})].

III Modeling and Problem Formulation

We consider the energy consumption minimization problem that involves a joint management of computation and communication resources, CH clustering, and device selection problem for the delay-constrained FL. As such, we evaluate the introduced FL scheme from communication and computation perspective. Therefore, first we provide FL time and total energy consumption expressions, and then we formulate the energy consumption minimization problem.

III-A FL Time and Energy Consumption

(1) FL time constraint: At the t𝑡t-th global iteration, the FL delay is caused by: (i) the computation time for local model training at the scheduled local devices 𝒩lsubscript𝒩𝑙\mathcal{N}_{l}; (ii) the transmission time for transmitting local trained updates to the associated CHs 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}; and (iii) the transmission time for transmitting the clusters aggregated models from the associated CHs to the scheduled devices 𝒩lsubscript𝒩𝑙\mathcal{N}_{l}.

The n𝑛n-th local device executes a local update algorithm until a local accuracy ϵlsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙\epsilon_{l} is achieved [37]. Let us denote Qnsubscript𝑄𝑛Q_{n} as the number of CPU cycles to process one data sample and fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} is the computational frequency of the CPU in the n𝑛n-th local device (in cycles per second). We obtain the number of CPU cycles of the n𝑛n-th local device in a one local iteration over its dataset 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} as Qn​Dnsubscript𝑄𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛Q_{n}D_{n} and the computation time for a one local iteration in the n𝑛n-th device as Qn​Dnfnsubscript𝑄𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛\frac{Q_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}} [38, 39]. The computation time of the n𝑛n-th local device is then expressed as

Tnc​o​m​p=Tl​Qn​Dnfn,subscriptsuperscript𝑇𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑝𝑛subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝑄𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛T^{comp}_{n}=T_{l}\frac{Q_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}}, (13)

where Tlsubscript𝑇𝑙T_{l} is the number of local iterations to reach the local accuracy ϵlsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙\epsilon_{l} in the n𝑛n-th local device. The training parameters of the local devices are considered to have a fixed size [40], and denote s𝑠s as parameter data size of the n𝑛n-th local device. Therefore, the transmission time of the n𝑛n-th local device for uploading its parameters to the c𝑐c-th CH on the z𝑧z-th RRB is Tnc​o​m=sRc,znsubscriptsuperscript𝑇𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑛𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑧𝑛T^{com}_{n}=\frac{s}{R_{c,z}^{n}}.

The aggregated model parameters can only be updated by the CHs after all local model parameters are received from the scheduled devices and BDs. Consequently, the FL time is dominated by the longest duration time of receiving the local parameters from all scheduled devices and the longest duration time of aggregated models from the CHs to its scheduled devices. Note that the transmission duration of the c𝑐c-th CH to transmit its aggregated parameter with size s𝑠s to its scheduled devices 𝒩lcsuperscriptsubscript𝒩𝑙𝑐\mathcal{N}_{l}^{c} is Tcc​o​m=maxn∈𝒩lc⁡{sRcn}subscriptsuperscript𝑇𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑐subscript𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑙𝑐𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑛𝑐T^{com}_{c}=\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{l}^{c}}\left\{\frac{s}{R^{n}_{c}}\right\}. Hence, the learning time τcsubscript𝜏𝑐\tau_{c} at the c𝑐c-th CH can be calculated as

Therefore, for each global iteration, the total learning time τ=maxc∈𝒞⁡(τc)𝜏subscript𝑐𝒞subscript𝜏𝑐\tau=\max_{c\in\mathcal{C}}(\tau_{c}), which should be no more than the QoS requirement (i.e., τ𝜏\tau should be no more than the maximum federated learning time Tmaxsubscript𝑇maxT_{\text{max}}). Typically, this constraint, over all global iterations T𝑇T, is expressed as

(2) Energy consumption: The total energy consumption of our considered system is caused by the following:

  • •

    The energy that is consumed due to local computation at the local devices, where the energy consumption of the n𝑛n-th local device to process a single CPU cycle is α​fn2𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓2𝑛\alpha f^{2}_{n}, and α𝛼\alpha is a constant related to the switched capacitance [39, 41].   • •

    The energy consumption to transmit local model parameters to the associated CHs can be denoted by Enc​o​msubscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑛E^{com}_{n} and calculated as pn​Tnc​o​msubscript𝑝𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑇𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑛p_{n}T^{com}_{n}. Let us denote the total energy consummation at the n𝑛n-th local device as En=Enc​o​m​p+Enc​o​msubscript𝐸𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑝𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑛E_{n}=E^{comp}_{n}+E^{com}_{n}. Similarly, the energy consumption to transmit the c𝑐c-th CH aggregated model to the associated local devices is denoted by Ecc​o​msubscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑐E^{com}_{c} and calculated as pc​Tcc​o​msubscript𝑝𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑇𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑐p_{c}T^{com}_{c}.

Therefore, the total energy consumption of our envisioned system can be calculated as

E𝐸\displaystyle E =T​{∑n∈𝒩lEn+∑c∈𝒞Ecc​o​m}absent𝑇subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑙subscript𝐸𝑛subscript𝑐𝒞subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑐\displaystyle=T\left\{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{l}}E_{n}+\sum_{c\in\mathcal{C}}E^{com}_{c}\right\}
=T​{∑n∈𝒩l[Tl​Qn​Dn​α​fn2+s​pnRc,zn]+∑c∈𝒞[s​pcRc]}.absent𝑇subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑙delimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝑄𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓2𝑛𝑠subscript𝑝𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑛𝑐𝑧subscript𝑐𝒞delimited-[]𝑠subscript𝑝𝑐subscript𝑅𝑐\displaystyle=T\left\{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{l}}\left[T_{l}Q_{n}D_{n}\alpha f^{2}_{n}+\frac{sp_{n}}{R^{n}_{c,z}}\right]+\sum_{c\in\mathcal{C}}\left[\frac{sp_{c}}{R_{c}}\right]\right\}. (16)

III-B Problem Formulation

We consider the following two binary optimization variables: (i) sn,csubscript𝑠𝑛𝑐s_{n,c} for device-CH scheduling; and (ii) rc,znsubscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑛𝑐𝑧r^{n}_{c,z} for device-RRB assignment. In addition, we consider the computation frequency allocation vector fN=[fn]subscriptfNdelimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑛\textbf{f}_{\text{N}}=[f_{n}]. The energy consumption minimization optimization problem is formulated as

s.t.{C1:​∑c∈𝒞sc,n=1&∑z∈𝒵rc,zn=1,∀n∈𝒩l,C2:​ℬc∩ℬc′=1,∀(c,c′)∈𝒞,C3:​fnmin≤fn≤fnmax,∀n∈𝒩l,C4:​τ≤Tmax,formulae-sequencestcasesformulae-sequenceC1:subscriptc𝒞subscriptscn1subscriptz𝒵subscriptsuperscriptrncz1for-allnsubscript𝒩lotherwiseformulae-sequenceC2:superscriptℬcsuperscriptℬsuperscriptc′1for-allcsuperscriptc′𝒞otherwiseformulae-sequenceC3:subscriptsuperscriptfnsubscriptfnsubscriptsuperscriptfnfor-allnsubscript𝒩lotherwiseC4:𝜏subscriptTmaxotherwise\displaystyle\rm s.t.\begin{cases}\hskip 5.69046pt\text{C1:}\hskip 5.69046pt\sum_{c\in\mathcal{C}}s_{c,n}=1~{}\&~{}\sum_{z\in\mathcal{Z}}r^{n}_{c,z}=1,\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{l},\\ \hskip 5.69046pt\text{C2:}\hskip 5.69046pt\mathcal{B}^{c}\cap\mathcal{B}^{c^{\prime}}=1,\forall(c,c^{\prime})\in\mathcal{C},\\ \hskip 5.69046pt\text{C3:}\hskip 5.69046ptf^{\min}_{n}\leq f_{n}\leq f^{\max}_{n},~{}\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{l},\\ \hskip 5.69046pt\text{C4:}\hskip 5.69046pt\tau\leq T_{\text{max}},\\ \end{cases}

In P0, C1 indicates that each local device is assigned to only one CH and to only one RRB in that CH; C2 indicates that at maximum one BD can be assigned to two adjacent CHs at the same time. In practice and due to the nature of D2D communications, we can have more than one BD at the overlap regions of adjacent CHs. In this case, the BD in the middle of overlapped regions is selected and other BDs are scheduled to the most suitable CHs. C3 is the constraint on local computation resource allocation of devices; and C4 indicates the QoS requirement on the FL time.

Hence, Tl​Qn​Dnfn+sRc,zn≤Tc,maxsubscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝑄𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑧𝑛subscript𝑇c,maxT_{l}\frac{Q_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}}+\frac{s}{R_{c,z}^{n}}\leq T_{\text{c,max}}, where Tc,max=TmaxT−sRcnsubscript𝑇c,maxsubscript𝑇max𝑇𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑛𝑐T_{\text{c,max}}=\frac{T_{\text{max}}}{T}-\frac{s}{R^{n}_{c}}. Hence, similar to [13], the lower bound of device’s computation frequency can be calculated as fn≥Tl​Qn​DnTc,max−sRc,znsubscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝑄𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝑇c,max𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑧𝑛f_{n}\geq\frac{T_{l}Q_{n}D_{n}}{T_{\text{c,max}}-\frac{s}{R_{c,z}^{n}}}. Then, fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} satisfies fn≥f^nsubscript𝑓𝑛subscript^𝑓𝑛f_{n}\geq\hat{f}_{n}, and accordingly, P0 can be transformed into

IV Proposed Solution

IV-A Proposed Solution Approach

Problem P1 is a mixed-integer non-linear programming problem as it involves a joint optimization of the continuous computation frequency allocation and discrete resource assignment variables (e.g., CH-devices/BD and RRB scheduling). In addition, the selection of CHs 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} and their scheduled local devices/BDs are inter-dependent and should be considered jointly. We can readily show that P1 is an NP-hard problem. Even if we fix one of these variables, P1 still remains NP-hard. An exhaustive search is required to obtain the global optimal solution of problem P1, which is infeasible in practical systems. To overcome the aforementioned computational intractability, an iterative approach is devised, where we decompose P1 into two sub-problems. Particularly, considering that fn∗​∀n∈𝒩lsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛for-all𝑛subscript𝒩𝑙f^{*}_{n}~{}\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{l} are given, the energy consumption can be obtained from the following optimization problem.

P2:​minsn,c∈{0,1},rc,zn∈{0,1},𝒞∈𝒫​(𝒩)⁡E​s.t.C1,C2,​C4.formulae-sequenceP2:subscriptformulae-sequencesubscript𝑠𝑛𝑐01subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑛𝑐𝑧01𝒞𝒫𝒩𝐸stC1C2,C4\displaystyle\text{P2:}\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}s_{n,c}\in\{0,1\},r^{n}_{c,z}\in\{0,1\},\\ \mathcal{C}\in\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{N})\end{subarray}}E~{}~{}\rm s.t.\hskip 5.69046pt\text{C1},\text{C2,}~{}\text{C4}. (19)

While for the given CH clustering and device-CH/RRB scheduling, the computation frequency allocation of the local devices are obtained by solving the following sub-problem

P3:​minfN⁡E​s.t.C3,C4.formulae-sequenceP3:subscriptsubscriptf𝑁𝐸stC3C4\displaystyle\text{P3:}\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}\textbf{f}_{N}\end{subarray}}E~{}~{}\rm s.t.\hskip 5.69046pt\text{C3},\text{C4}. (20)

A suitable solution to P1 is obtained by iteratively solving the sub-problems P2 and P3. The sub-problems P2 and P3 are solved in Section IV-C and Section IV-D, respectively, and the overall algorithm to solve P1 is provided in Section V-A.

IV-B CH, BD, and Local Device Scheduling: P2 Reformulation

It is recalled that the set of CHs is 𝒞∈𝒫​(𝒩)𝒞𝒫𝒩\mathcal{C}\in\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{N}). Let κc​(𝒞)subscript𝜅𝑐𝒞\kappa_{c}(\mathcal{C}) be the set of scheduled local devices that are associated to CH c∈𝒞𝑐𝒞c\in\mathcal{C}. Note that κc​(𝒞)subscript𝜅𝑐𝒞\kappa_{c}(\mathcal{C}) is a function of the set of CHs 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}. However, for convenience, the set will be dropped unless it is required, e.g., we will use κcsubscript𝜅𝑐\kappa_{c} instead of κc​(𝒞)subscript𝜅𝑐𝒞\kappa_{c}(\mathcal{C}).

P2 considers a joint optimization of both CHs selection and their scheduled devices and BDs, denoted by 𝒞∈𝒫​(𝒩)𝒞𝒫𝒩\mathcal{C}\in\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{N}), 𝒩lsubscript𝒩𝑙\mathcal{N}_{l}, and ℬℬ\mathcal{B}, respectively. In particular, P2 involves inner and outer optimization problems: the inner one optimizes the device/BD scheduling to reduce the network utility function while the outer one aims at finding the most suitable CHs. Therefore, the joint inner and outer optimization sub-problem P2, for a given fn∗​∀n∈𝒩lsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛for-all𝑛subscript𝒩𝑙f^{*}_{n}~{}\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{l}, can be given at the top of the next page.

Unfortunately, the outer optimization problem (21) and the inner optimization problem (22) of P2.1 are inter-dependent and should be solved jointly. Solving P2.1 optimally using an exhaustive search is intractable [42, 43]. In this work, we develop a tractable graph theoretical and clustering method that carefully selects the number of clusters, their corresponding CHs, and scheduled local devices/BDs. As such, it achieves an effective solution to the optimization problem P2.1.

IV-C CH Clustering and Local Device/BD Scheduling: Solution to P2.1

(1) Graph representation: We first design a conflict graph that considers the restrictions in device-CH/RRB scheduling and the partial connectivity of the CHs. In this context, a conflict graph is constructed for each device c𝑐c in the network and denoted by 𝒢c​(𝒱c,ℰc)subscript𝒢𝑐subscript𝒱𝑐subscriptℰ𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c}(\mathcal{V}_{c},\mathcal{E}_{c}) wherein 𝒱csubscript𝒱𝑐\mathcal{V}_{c} and ℰcsubscriptℰ𝑐\mathcal{E}_{c} are the set of vertices and edges, respectively. Since each device c𝑐c can schedule local devices in its coverage zone 𝒜csubscript𝒜𝑐\mathcal{A}_{c} only, a vertex vc,nz∈𝒱csubscriptsuperscript𝑣𝑧𝑐𝑛subscript𝒱𝑐v^{z}_{c,n}\in\mathcal{V}_{c} is generated for each local device n∈𝒜c𝑛subscript𝒜𝑐n\in\mathcal{A}_{c} and for each RRB z𝑧z. In the conflict graph, two distinct vertices vc,nzsubscriptsuperscript𝑣𝑧𝑐𝑛v^{z}_{c,n} and vc,n′z′subscriptsuperscript𝑣superscript𝑧′𝑐superscript𝑛′v^{z^{\prime}}_{c,n^{\prime}} are adjacent by a scheduling conflict edge if one of the following cases occurs:

  • •

    CC1: The same local device is associated with both vertices vc,nzsubscriptsuperscript𝑣𝑧𝑐𝑛v^{z}_{c,n} and vc,n′z′subscriptsuperscript𝑣superscript𝑧′𝑐superscript𝑛′v^{z^{\prime}}_{c,n^{\prime}}, i.e., n=n′𝑛superscript𝑛′n=n^{\prime}.

  • •

    CC2: The same RRB is associated with both vertices vc,nzsubscriptsuperscript𝑣𝑧𝑐𝑛v^{z}_{c,n} and vc,n′z′subscriptsuperscript𝑣superscript𝑧′𝑐superscript𝑛′v^{z^{\prime}}_{c,n^{\prime}}, i.e., z=z′𝑧superscript𝑧′z=z^{\prime} and n≠n′𝑛superscript𝑛′n\neq n^{\prime}.

Recall that each selected CH is granted a limited number of Z𝑍Z RRBs. Thus, each CH can schedule at maximum Z𝑍Z local devices, and the maximum of Z𝑍Z vertices can be represented by the minimum-weight independent set (MWIS) in the conflict graph. In what follows, we transform problem (22) into a MWIS problem. First, we present the following remarks about the MWIS.

  • •

    Any independent set (IS) κcsubscript𝜅𝑐\kappa_{c} in the conflict graph 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} must satisfy: i) κc⊆𝒢csubscript𝜅𝑐subscript𝒢𝑐\kappa_{c}\subseteq\mathcal{G}_{c}; ii) ∀v,v′∈κcfor-all𝑣superscript𝑣′subscript𝜅𝑐\forall v,v^{\prime}\in\kappa_{c}, where (v,v′)∉ℰc𝑣superscript𝑣′subscriptℰ𝑐(v,v^{\prime})\notin\mathcal{E}_{c}.

  • •

    A minimal IS in an undirected graph cannot be expanded to add one more vertex without affecting the pairwise non-adjacent vertices.

  • •

    The IS κcsubscript𝜅𝑐\kappa_{c} is referred to an MWIS of 𝒢csubscript𝒢c\mathcal{G}_{\text{c}} if it satisfies: i) κcsubscript𝜅𝑐\kappa_{c} is an IS in graph 𝒢csubscript𝒢c\mathcal{G}_{\text{c}}; ii) the sum weights of the vertices in κcsubscript𝜅𝑐\kappa_{c} offers the minimum among all ISs of 𝒢csubscript𝒢c\mathcal{G}_{\text{c}}. Therefore, the MWIS will be denoted as κc∗subscriptsuperscript𝜅𝑐\kappa^{*}_{c}.

Given 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c}, the optimization problem (22) for a fixed fn∗​∀n∈𝒩lsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛for-all𝑛subscript𝒩𝑙f^{*}_{n}~{}\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{l} is similar to MWIS problems. In MWIS problems, two vertices must be non-adjacent in the conflict graph, which is similar to problem (22), where two local devices cannot be allocated with the same RRB. Likewise, the same RRB cannot be allocated to two different local devices. Furthermore, the objective of (22) is to minimize the energy consumption, while the goal of MWIS is to select a set of vertices with minimum weights. Hence, the following corollary characterizes the solution of the optimization problem (22).

Corollary 1.

The solution κc∗​(𝒞)subscriptsuperscript𝜅𝑐𝒞\kappa^{*}_{c}(\mathcal{C}) of the optimization problem (22) for device c𝑐c is the MWIS κc∗subscriptsuperscript𝜅𝑐\kappa^{*}_{c} in the conflict graph 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} of device c𝑐c in which the weight of each vertex vc,nzsubscriptsuperscript𝑣𝑧𝑐𝑛v^{z}_{c,n} is w​(vc,nz)=Tl​Qn​Dnfn∗+sRc,zn𝑤subscriptsuperscript𝑣𝑧𝑐𝑛subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝑄𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑧𝑛w(v^{z}_{c,n})=T_{l}\frac{Q_{n}D_{n}}{f^{*}_{n}}+\frac{s}{R_{c,z}^{n}}.

(2) CH Clustering: Essentially, two adjacent clusters are formed, and accordingly, their corresponding CHs can simultaneously transmit the aggregated models to the scheduled local devices if the CHs’ coverage zones are overlapped by at least one BD. This is to ensure that the shared BD can exchange the received aggregated models to the adjacent CHs.

We construct the whole set of clusters 𝐅𝐅\mathbf{F} such that: (i) all coverage zones of adjacent clusters F∈𝐅𝐹𝐅F\in\mathbf{F} are pairwise overlapped by one BD; and (ii) within the same cluster F𝐹F, each subset of local devices is interfering with at least another local device. Mathematically, the clusters in 𝐅𝐅\mathbf{F} should satisfy: (i) 𝐅={F∈𝒫​(𝒩)|𝒜c∩𝒜t​o​t​(F\c)≠∅,∀c∈F}𝐅conditional-set𝐹𝒫𝒩formulae-sequencesubscript𝒜𝑐superscript𝒜𝑡𝑜𝑡\𝐹𝑐for-all𝑐𝐹\mathbf{F}=\{F\in\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{N})~{}|\mathcal{A}_{c}\cap\mathcal{A}^{tot}(F\backslash c)\neq\emptyset,\forall c\in F\}; (ii) 𝒜t​o​t​(F)∩𝒜t​o​t​(F′)=1,∀(F,F′)∈𝐅formulae-sequencesuperscript𝒜𝑡𝑜𝑡𝐹superscript𝒜𝑡𝑜𝑡superscript𝐹′1for-all𝐹superscript𝐹′𝐅\mathcal{A}^{tot}(F)\cap\mathcal{A}^{tot}(F^{\prime})=1,\forall(F,F^{\prime})\in\mathbf{F}. Therefore, we have the following lemma for the overlapped clustering construction.

Lemma 1.

For any particular set 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}, the corresponding overlapped clustering ℱ∈𝐅ℱ𝐅\mathcal{F}\in\mathbf{F} satisfies the following constraints

⨁F∈ℱF=𝒞subscriptdirect-sum𝐹ℱ𝐹𝒞\displaystyle\bigoplus_{F\in\mathcal{F}}F=\mathcal{C} (23a)
𝒜t​o​t​(F)∩𝒜t​o​t​(F′)=1,∀F≠F′∈ℱ,formulae-sequencesuperscript𝒜𝑡𝑜𝑡𝐹superscript𝒜𝑡𝑜𝑡superscript𝐹′1for-all𝐹superscript𝐹′ℱ\displaystyle\mathcal{A}^{tot}(F)\cap\mathcal{A}^{tot}(F^{\prime})=1,\forall F\neq F^{\prime}\in\mathcal{F}, (23b)

where 𝒜t​o​t​(F)superscript𝒜𝑡𝑜𝑡𝐹\mathcal{A}^{tot}(F) is the total coverage zone of all local devices in the cluster F𝐹F defined as 𝒜t​o​t​(F)=∪c∈F𝒜csuperscript𝒜𝑡𝑜𝑡𝐹subscript𝑐𝐹subscript𝒜𝑐\mathcal{A}^{tot}(F)=\cup_{c\in F}\mathcal{A}_{c}. Thus, for any 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}, there exists a clustering ℱℱ\mathcal{F} satisfying the constraints (23a), (23b), and (23c) simultaneously. In (23a), ⨁direct-sum\bigoplus denotes a partition symbol.

Proof.

The proof is analogous to [43, Lemma 1], and is omitted due to the space limitation. ∎

It is recalled that local devices can only communicate with their respective neighbors over a wireless D2D link whose connectivity can be characterized by an undirected graph 𝒢​(𝒱,ℰ)𝒢𝒱ℰ\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}) with 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} denoting the set of vertices and ℰℰ\mathcal{E} the set of edges. To design a scheduling scheme meeting the aforementioned clustering properties, we construct the graph 𝒢​(𝒱,ℰ)𝒢𝒱ℰ\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}) as follows. We represent a cluster F𝐹F by a vertex V𝑉V in the graph, and two vertices are connected by a scheduling link if the represented clusters are satisfying (23b). Next, to select the device-CH/RRB scheduling that provides a minimum energy consumption while maximizing the number of scheduled local devices in each cluster and guarantees the FL time constraint, we assign a weight w​(V)𝑤𝑉w(V) to each vertex V∈𝒱𝑉𝒱V\in\mathcal{V}. For notation simplicity, we define the utility of the n𝑛n-th local device as En=Tl​Qn​Dnfn∗+sRc,znsubscript𝐸𝑛subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝑄𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑧𝑛E_{n}=T_{l}\frac{Q_{n}D_{n}}{f^{*}_{n}}+\frac{s}{R_{c,z}^{n}} and the utility of cluster F𝐹F represented by vertex V𝑉V as w​(V)=∑n∈κc∗En+Ecc​o​m𝑤𝑉subscript𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝜅𝑐subscript𝐸𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑐w(V)=\sum_{n\in\kappa^{*}_{c}}E_{n}+E^{com}_{c}. Therefore, the following theorem characterizes the solution to the energy consumption minimization problem P2.1, for a given fn∗​∀n∈𝒩lsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛for-all𝑛subscript𝒩𝑙f^{*}_{n}~{}\forall n\in\mathcal{N}_{l}, in a partially connected D2D network.

Theorem 1.

The solution to the energy consumption minimization problem P2.1 in the partially connected D2D network is equivalent to the weighting-search method, in which the weight of each vertex V𝑉V representing cluster F𝐹F is

w​(V)=∑n∈κc∗En+Ecc​o​m,𝑤𝑉subscript𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝜅𝑐subscript𝐸𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑐𝑜𝑚𝑐\displaystyle w(V)=\sum_{n\in\kappa^{*}_{c}}E_{n}+E^{com}_{c}, (24)

where κc∗subscriptsuperscript𝜅𝑐\kappa^{*}_{c} is the MWIS problem in the conflict graph of CH k𝑘k for device scheduling

κc∗=arg⁡minκc∈𝒢c⁡(∑n∈κc(Tl​Qn​Dnfn∗+sRc,zn)).subscriptsuperscript𝜅𝑐subscriptsubscript𝜅𝑐subscript𝒢𝑐subscript𝑛subscript𝜅𝑐subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝑄𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑐𝑧𝑛\displaystyle\kappa^{*}_{c}=\arg\min_{\mathtt{\kappa}_{c}\in\mathcal{G}_{c}}\left(\sum_{n\in\kappa_{c}}\left(T_{l}\frac{Q_{n}D_{n}}{f^{*}_{n}}+\frac{s}{R_{c,z}^{n}}\right)\right). (25)

Essentially, any possible solution to P2.1 using Theorem 1, representing CHs selection and their scheduled local devices, satisfies the following criteria: (i) the represented local devices by vertices in the conflict graph are scheduled to the best CHs/RRBs such that they transmit their local parameters quickly; (ii) the represented CH in each vertex is selected, so as it has a good reachability to many local devices in its coverage as well as it is overlapped with the neighboring CHs. This does not only increase the number of selected local devices that can participate in the training process, but also minimizes the number of clusters; and (iii) a vertex (representing by a subset of local devices) with a smaller weight (representing a sum of their consumed energy) will have a higher priority to be selected in participating in the training process to minimize the objective of P2.1.

The overall steps of cluster generation, conflict graph construction, and MWIS selection to obtain the CH clustering and device scheduling over the scheduled RRBs are summarized in Algorithm 1.

IV-D Computation Frequency Allocation: Solution to Sub-problem P3

For the resulting selected CHs and their scheduled devices from solving P2.1, sub-problem P3 is reduced to the following sub-problem

Lemma 2.

The closed-form solution of sub-problem P4 is obtained as

fn={fnmin,if​f^n≤fnminf^n,if​fnmin<f^n<fnmaxfnmax,if​f^n≥fnmax,subscript𝑓𝑛casesotherwisesubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛ifsubscript^𝑓𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛otherwisesubscript^𝑓𝑛ifsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛subscript^𝑓𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛otherwisesubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛ifsubscript^𝑓𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛\begin{split}f_{n}=\begin{cases}&f^{\min}_{n},~{}\text{if}~{}\hat{f}_{n}\leq f^{\min}_{n}\\ &\hat{f}_{n},~{}\text{if}~{}f^{\min}_{n}<\hat{f}_{n}<f^{\max}_{n}\\ &f^{\max}_{n},~{}\text{if}~{}\hat{f}_{n}\geq f^{\max}_{n},\end{cases}\end{split} (27)

V Development and Properties Of The Proposed FL-EOCD Algorithm

V-A Overview of the FL-EOCD Algorithm

The overall steps followed by the proposed FL-EOCD algorithm to obtain a suitable solution to problem P0 are summarized in Algorithm 2. FL-EOCD has two stages, namely, Stage-I and Stage-II.

(1) Stage-I: The required steps to implement Stage-I are provided as follows. At the beginning, the BS obtains the locations of the devices. Thereafter, based on the current computation frequency allocation, the BS designs the FL local graph of each device and judiciously finds the suitable CH clustering and the local device scheduling. Specifically, in order to determine the CHs and schedule the devices, the BS constructs the clustering and the corresponding graph, and then performs the greedy vertex-weighting algorithm [44, 45]. First, the BS selects the vertex that has the following features: (i) it has a minimum weight in terms of energy consumption and (ii) it is connected to many neighbors that have minimum weights. Next, it constructs the set of vertices that are connected to the selected vertex, and then finds the second minimum-weight vertex. This process is repeated until no neighbors are available in the designed clustering, and this is summarized in lines 21-25 of Algorithm 1. Meanwhile, the BS calculates the FL time of the scheduled devices according to (17) to check the feasibility of the scheduled local devices. Next, for each scheduled device, the BS updates the variable fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n}. The aforementioned steps are iteratively repeated until the computation frequency allocation constraints over all the scheduled local devices are satisfied or the maximum number of iterations is reached. Upon convergence in Stage-I (i.e., lines 3-7 of Algorithm 2), the set of CH clustering, device/BD scheduling, and computation frequency allocation among the scheduled local devices are obtained.

(1) Stage-II: To efficiently disseminate the local cluster aggregated models and perform FL of the CHs obtained by Stage-I, Stage-II is introduced in the FL-EOCD algorithm. In this stage, three main tasks are performed: (i) local learning at the associated devices; (ii) models combination and forwarding at the BDs; and (iii) cluster model aggregations at the CHs. The obtained CHs from Stage-1 transmit their initial models 𝐰ci​(t)subscript𝐰subscript𝑐𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{c_{i}}(t) to the associated devices and BDs. Afterword, the associated devices execute the local learning algorithm to update their local optimal models. Meanwhile, the BDs receive the updated models from the CHs and calculate the summation of the received aggregated models. The CHs, consequently, collect all the local models from the associated devices and the models from the BDs to update their cluster models according to (2). The aforementioned two stages are repeated until the maximum number of global iterations is reached. Upon convergence in Stage-II, the final global model is obtained.

V-B Computational and Signaling Cost of FL-EOCD

(1) Computational Complexity: We first analyze the computational complexity of Stage-I of the FL-EOCD algorithm. The required computational complexity of Stage-I is dominated by the complexity of constructing the cooperation clusters. This needs a computational complexity of 𝒪​(|𝐅|)𝒪𝐅\mathcal{O}(|\mathbf{F}|). Then, checking the neighbors of all these clusters requires a computational complexity of 𝒪​(|𝐅|2)𝒪superscript𝐅2\mathcal{O}(|\mathbf{F}|^{2}) [42, 43]. On the other hand, designing local graphs and finding the corresponding solution requires a computational complexity of 𝒪​(N​Na​v​g+N​Z)𝒪𝑁subscript𝑁𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑁𝑍\mathcal{O}(NN_{avg}+NZ), where Na​v​gsubscript𝑁𝑎𝑣𝑔N_{avg} is the average number of connected devices to any device in the network. Therefore, the overall computational complexity of Stage-I of the FL-EOCD algorithm is therefore obtained as 𝒪​(|𝐅|2+N​Na​v​g+N​Z)𝒪superscript𝐅2𝑁subscript𝑁𝑎𝑣𝑔𝑁𝑍\mathcal{O}(|\mathbf{F}|^{2}+NN_{avg}+NZ). Thus, FL-EOCD requires a polynomial computational complexity to obtain a converged solution.

(2) Signaling Overhead: At each iteration of the FL-EOCD algorithm, the BS executes Algorithm 1 that has a required signaling overhead as follows. At each iteration of Algorithm 1, devices first transmit their channel state information (CSI) and the indices of devices in their coverage zones to the BS. In this phase, at most 2​N2𝑁2N information exchanges are required. Subsequently, the BS executes Algorithm 1 and transmits the resulting device scheduling and BD selections to the CHs, which needs at most Ncsubscript𝑁𝑐N_{c} information exchanges. In this phase, a total of 2​N+Nc2𝑁subscript𝑁𝑐2N+N_{c} information exchanges are required for Algorithm 1. Until the convergence of Algorithm 1, a total number of the required information exchanges is obtained as Kmax​(2​N+Nc)subscript𝐾2𝑁subscript𝑁𝑐K_{\max}(2N+N_{c}), where Km​a​xsubscript𝐾𝑚𝑎𝑥K_{max} is the maximum number of iterations for solving P2 and P4. Each device needs to transmit its model parameter to the scheduled CH, and this requires Nc​Nlcsubscript𝑁𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑁𝑐𝑙N_{c}N^{c}_{l} information exchanges for all the clusters. In addition, CHs need to broadcast their global models to the scheduled devices and BDs, which requires Ncsubscript𝑁𝑐N_{c} information exchanges. Therefore, a total of T​(Kmax​(2​N+Nc)+Nc​Nlc+Nc)𝑇subscript𝐾2𝑁subscript𝑁𝑐subscript𝑁𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑁𝑐𝑙subscript𝑁𝑐T(K_{\max}(2N+N_{c})+N_{c}N^{c}_{l}+N_{c}) information exchanges are required between the devices and the BS during the execution of the FL-EOCD algorithm.

VI Numerical Results

VI-A Simulation Setting and Schemes Under Consideration

(1) Network configuration: For the numerical performance evaluations, we consider a circular network area having a radius of 900900900 m with one BS at its center and multiple randomly distributed devices. The channel model for D2D transmissions follows the standard model [22], which consists of three components: 1) path-loss of 148+40​log10⁡(dis.[km])14840subscript10dis.[km]148+40\log_{10}(\text{dis.[km]}); 2) log-normal shadowing with 444 dB standard deviation; and 3) Rayleigh channel fading with zero-mean and unit variance. On the other hand, the path-loss of the cellular is 128.1+37.6​log10⁡(dis.[km])128.137.6subscript10dis.[km]128.1+37.6\log_{10}(\text{dis.[km]}) [35, 36]. We consider that the channels are perfectly estimated. The noise power and maximum local device (BD and CH) power are assumed to be −174174-174 dBm/Hz and pn=pc=1subscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑝𝑐1p_{n}=p_{c}=1 W, respectively. The transmit power of the BS is set to 333 W. The bandwidth of each RRB is 222 MHz. Unless otherwise stated, we set the numbers of devices to 262626 and we consider 222222 RRBs in the system. The remaining simulation parameters that are selected based on [12, 13] are summarized in Table I. In the ensuing simulation results, each simulation experiment is repeated 200200200 times with randomly generated devices’ locations, and the average results over all the considered simulation instances are presented. We consider a deep learning image classification problem over MNIST dataset [27]. The considered dataset contains 606060 K images, where each image is one of 101010 labels. We divide the dataset into the devices’ local data 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} with non-i.i.d. data heterogeneity, where each local dataset contains datapoints from two of the 101010 labels. In each case, 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} is selected randomly from the full dataset of labels assigned to n𝑛n-th device. We also assume non-iid-clustering, where the maximum number of assigned classes for each cluster is 666 classes. For ML models, we use a deep neural network with 333 convolutional layers and 111 fully connected layer. The total number of trainable parameters is 909890989098.

(3) Schemes Under Consideration: To showcase the effectiveness of the proposed FL-EOCD scheme in terms of energy consumption and latency, we consider the following FL benchmark schemes.

  • •

    Star-based FL: Here, instead of local cluster aggregations at the CHs, the scheduled devices upload their local models directly to the BS for a global model aggregation. At the BS, an averaging FL scheme is applied to calculate the global model to be transmitted to the scheduled devices for initiating the next iteration of local learning. For a fair comparison, the performance of the centralized FL is optimized by leveraging the FL-EOCD framework. In particular, Algorithm 1 is used to obtain the devices-RRBs scheduling and computation frequency allocation to minimize the energy consumption.

  • •

    Hierarchical FL: Here, instead of transmitting the local models from scheduled devices directly to the BS, the selected CHs collect the local models from their devices and forward them to the BS for a global aggregation. For a fair comparison, the performance of the hierarchical FL is optimized by leveraging the FL-EOCD framework. In particular, we optimize the CH selection, device scheduling, and computation frequency allocation.

VI-B Performance of the Proposed FL-EOCD and Benchmark Schemes for Studying the Accuracy and Number of Iterations for Different Overlapped Clustering

In Fig. 4, we plot the accuracy of the proposed FL-EOCD and benchmark schemes versus the number of global iterations for a network of 222222 RRBs and 262626 devices which are grouped into 333 overlapped clusters. In the considered star-based and hierarchical FL schemes, the BS can receive the local trained models of the devices, where each scheduled device transmits its trained model directly to the BS (in case of star-based FL) or through CHs (in case of hierarchical FL). As a result, the BS can aggregate all the local models and reaches accuracy of 88%percent8888\% and 86%percent8686\% with around 202020 global iterations for star-based and hierarchical FL schemes, respectively. In the considered decentralized system, at the beginning, each selected CH has the knowledge of the cluster model that depends on its scheduled devices in the corresponding cluster. Consequently, FL-EOCD has a low accuracy of 82%percent8282\% at 202020 iterations compared to the aforementioned schemes. Thus, our proposed scheme has a certain delay of reaching the same accuracy of the other schemes for a few number of iterations. However, using the efficient overlapped clustering and aggregated models dissemination between CHs, the proposed FL-EOCD algorithm efficiently disseminates the aggregated models of CHs to their adjacent clusters. Consequently, with increasing the number of iterations, the CHs have better knowledge about the global model of the system. Thus, the accuracy of our proposed FL-EOCD scheme is quickly increased with the number of iterations. Essentially, when the number of global iterations in the range of 150−200150200150-200, the CHs in the proposed scheme have almost the same global model of the BS of the star-based and hierarchical FL schemes. Therefore, as depicted from Fig. 4, all the considered schemes have almost the same number of global iterations upon reaching the accuracy of 96%percent9696\%.

In Fig. 5, we further study the impact of the number of overlapped clusters on the convergence rate of our proposed FL-EOCD scheme compared to the benchmark schemes for a network of 222222 RRBs and 262626 devices which are clustered into 444 overlapped clusters. From Fig. 5, when the number of iterations is 404040, FL-EOCD reaches an accuracy of 88%percent8888\% for 444 overlapped clusters as opposed to 90%percent9090\% for 333 overlapped clusters as depicted in Fig. 4. Thus, the performance gain of FL-EOCD is not degraded for a few number of iterations with relatively large number of clusters, thanks to the efficient overlapped clustering and models’ dissemination achieved by FL-EOCD. Again, for a large number of global iterations, FL-EOCD achieves the same accuracy as the FL benchmark schemes without the need for global aggregations at the BS.

VI-C Performance of the Proposed FL-EOCD and Benchmark Schemes in terms of Energy Consumption and FL Time

In Fig. 6, we evaluate the accuracy of the proposed FL-EOCD and benchmark schemes versus the required consumed energy in a network of 262626 devices and 222222 RRBs. From Fig. 4, we observe that for same accuracy and number of global iterations, the energy consumption of the proposed FL-EOCD is reduced. Such an observation can be explained by the following argument. In the proposed FL-EOCD scheme, we judiciously select the CHs such that they have good reachability to many close-by local devices. Thus, the consumed energy for wireless transmissions from devices/BDs to CHs and then from CHs back to devices/BDs is low. However, in the considered star-based FL, devices consume most of the energy for transmitting their trained local models to the distant BS. Consequently, a degradation of the energy consumption is observed at 200200200 iterations when the star-based FL converges. It is recalled that in the hierarchical FL, unlike the proposed FL-EOCD, two-hop transmission is required which consumes more energy. As a result, FL-EOCD achieves an improved energy consumption compared to the considered hierarchical FL scheme. Fig. 4 demonstrates that FL-EOCD requires energy of 0.510.510.51 J compared to the consumed energy of the considered star-based FL and hierarchical schemes of 0.980.980.98 J and 0.690.690.69 J, respectively, for 200200200 global iterations. Furthermore, since FL-EOCD requires polynomial computational complexity and has an improved performance in terms of energy consumption, it is advantageous compared to the benchmark FL schemes.

In Fig. 7, we evaluate the accuracy of the proposed FL-EOCD and benchmark schemes versus the FL time in a network of 262626 devices and 222222 RRBs. First, it is clear that the FL time depends on the wireless transmission time and the computation learning time of devices. Since all the simulated schemes consider local learning at the devices and optimize the frequency allocation computation, their local learning time is almost the same. Thus, the key factor in the FL time is the communication time of transmitting the trained local models to the CHs/BS plus the transmitting time of sending the aggregated models from CHs/BS back to the devices. Consequently, the FL time is dominated by the wireless transmission time. As can be seen from Fig. 5, our proposed FL-ECD scheme, that implements simultaneous and short D2D communications, effectively minimizes the FL time with the same accuracy of the considered benchmark schemes. In particular, it can be observed that the FL time of FL-EOCD at 200200200 iterations is 0.0310.0310.031 second while the considered star-based and hierarchical schemes have FL times of 0.0450.0450.045 second and 0.0710.0710.071 second at the same number of iterations, respectively. This is because the FL time is mainly controlled by the longest transmission time of one device, named as a straggler device, which comes in favor of our proposed FL-EOCD scheme, thanks to the clustering optimization, CH-device scheduling, computation frequency allocation, and D2D communications.

Figs. 6 and 7 interestingly depict that the star-based FL has a poor performance in terms of energy consumption and improved FL time compared to the hierarchical FL. This argument is due to the fact that hierarchical FL has good and short connectivity among devices which consumes less energy, however it needs two-hop transmission that degrades the FL latency. Our proposed FL-EOCD strikes a balance between these benchmark schemes by (i) augmenting the need for two hops of transmission (unlike hierarchical FL); and (ii) ensuring short-range of communications between CHs and devices/BDs (unlike the star-based FL that requires a distant BS).

VI-D Performance of the Proposed FL-EOCD and Benchmark Schemes for Different Number of Devices and RRBs

In Figs. 8(a) and 8(b), we evaluate the energy consumption and FL time for one global iteration, respectively, of the proposed FL-EOCD and benchmark schemes by varying the number of devices in a network of 303030 RRBs. From Fig. 8, we observe that FL-EOCD outperforms the benchmark schemes in terms of energy consumption and FL time. For instance, Fig. 8(a) shows that FL-EOCD achieves 0.00270.00270.0027 J and 0.00130.00130.0013 J lower energy consumption, respectively, than the considered star-based and hierarchical schemes for 202020 devices. It is noteworthy that when N𝑁N increases, the consumed energy of all the schemes increases. However, due to the D2D short communications and efficient overlapped clustering of our proposed FL-EOCD scheme, the power consumption degradation for increasing N𝑁N is insignificant, thanks to the joint clustering and device scheduling achieved by our proposed scheme for the increased number of devices. Indeed, Fig. 8(a) shows that FL-EOCD achieves 0.00320.00320.0032 J lower energy consumption compared the considered star-based scheme for 303030 devices. Similarly, Fig. 8(b) shows that FL-EOCD achieves 0.170.170.17 ms and 0.050.050.05 ms shorter FL time than the considered hierarchical and star-based schemes for 505050 devices, respectively. It is noted that the star-based FL can support at a maximum of 303030 devices that is equal to the number of available RRBs in the system. Therefore, the energy consumption and FL time performances of the star-based FL do not grow up with increasing the number of devices (N>30𝑁30N>30). Based on Fig. 8(a) and Fig. 8(b), we conclude that the proposed FL-EOCD algorithm is efficient in terms of energy consumption and FL time for both small and large numbers of devices.

In Fig. 9, we evaluate the number of scheduled devices of the proposed FL-EOCD and benchmark schemes by changing the number of devices in a network of 505050 RRBs (solid lines) and 252525 RRBs (dash lines). From Fig. 9, we observe that for both FL-EOCD and hierarchical schemes, the number of scheduled devices is degraded as compared to the considered star-based FL scheme. Both schemes have a certain degradation, around 7%percent77\%, compared to the star-based scheme where the number of scheduled devices grows relatively fast. This is becasue in the considered star-based FL scheme, the BS can access all the devices, and thus it can schedule all the devices in the network, given the number of RRBs in the network. On the other hand, in FL-EOCD scheme, the selected overlapped CHs have limited coverage range and cannot schedule all the devices in the network. Following this, the remaining devices are unscheduled. Consequently, a degradation in the number of scheduled devices is observed in case of large numbers of devices in the network.

Fig. 9 also illustrates that the proposed FL-EOCD algorithm and hierarchical scheme outperform the considered star-based scheme when the number of RRBs is less than the number of devices. In particular, when Z𝑍Z is nearly 252525, the effective system capacity of the star-based scheme stops growing and can have at most 252525 scheduled devices. Therefore, the star-based scheme is impractical in terms of the number of scheduled devices, particularly for massive networks with limited radio resources. However, in the considered D2D schemes (i.e., FL-EOCD and hierarchical), the set of RRBs can be re-used among non-adjacent clusters. As a result, the number of scheduled devices of the considered D2D schemes is increased. Indeed, Fig. 9 (dash lines) demonstrates that D2D schemes achieve more than 25%percent2525\% improvement in the number of scheduled devices compared to the star-based FL for 505050 devices and 252525 RRBs in the network.

VII Concluding Remarks and Future Works

In this paper, we have introduced a new FL-EOCD scheme, that leverages D2D communications and overlapped clustering without the need for a global aggregator. In order to study the performance of the developed FL-EOCD scheme, second we have investigated the resource allocation strategy to minimize the energy consumption in a partially connected D2D network subject to FL time constraint. Our proposed resource allocation strategy jointly optimizes the clustering selection, CH-device scheduling, and frequency computation allocation. The presented numerical results revealed that the proposed FL-EOCD scheme substantially reduces the energy consumption and FL time compared to the baseline schemes. In particular, simulation results showed that the proposed FL-EOCD scheme can effectively improve the energy consumption by around 35%percent3535\% and 55%percent5555\%, and FL time by around 50%percent5050\% and 30%percent3030\%, respectively, compared to the hierarchical and star-based schemes. For the required accuracy of 80%percent8080\%, our proposed FL-EOCD scheme has a certain degradation in the number of global iterations as compared to the benchmark schemes. This small degradation in some numerical results, roughly in the range of 333-555 global iterations, comes at the achieved: (i) low energy consumption and (ii) reduced FL time without using a global aggregator as compared to the benchmark schemes.

In this paper, due to the space limitation, we have numerically proved the convergence rate of our proposed FL-EOCD scheme, and the mathematical analysis of the convergence rate is left for a future work. As an extension, it is also possible to alleviate the existence of a global coordinator (e.g., BS) by developing a game theoretical approach.
